review: The story introduces Mike Bowditch, an investigator with the Maine Warden Service, who learns of an armed man searching for a reclusive father and daughter, Mark Redmond and Cady. As Mike and his father-in-law, Charley Stevens, enlist the help of Charley's friend Josie to locate them, their attempt to meet Mark and Cady takes a sinister turn, unveiling secrets Mark is desperate to protect. The narrative unfolds as Mike navigates the treacherous Maine wilderness, grappling with inclement weather and a formidable adversary, while facing complications from a bounty hunter and sympathetic locals aiding Mark. Filled with action, adventure, and shocking twists, this story promises an exhilarating read.

Mike Bowditch stands out as an intriguing protagonist, particularly through his complex relationship with his father-in-law, Charley Stevens. Mark Redmond emerges as a skilled and formidable adversary, setting the stage for a gripping cat-and-mouse dynamic. The supporting characters, including Josie and the bounty hunter, are well-developed and enrich the narrative. However, a minor critique is that Stacey, a recurring character, could have played a more active role in this installment.
The sharp writing and fast-paced, suspenseful narrative captivated me until the very end.
The vivid, atmospheric setting of the Maine wilderness heightens the story's tension and immersion. The harsh weather and rugged terrain amplify the suspense and danger throughout the narrative.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* by the author is a gripping novel, offering a vivid setting, sharp writing, and a suspenseful narrative filled with action and surprises. While I wished for a more active role for Stacey, the compelling characters, superb development, and thrilling plot made this a highly enjoyable read. The book works well as a standalone, and the audiobook narration enhanced the experience. I look forward to exploring more books.

review: This novel captivates readers with intense action and suspense from the outset to its exhilarating conclusion. The fast-paced plot features unexpected twists and is darker than previous installments. Although some plot points may be predictable, the overall tension and rapid pace remain highly engaging. While the main mystery is resolved, a few loose ends hint at developments in the next book. The suspense is masterfully crafted, resulting in a pulse-pounding reading experience.

Mike Bowditch is a multifaceted protagonist, characterized by his fiery personality, sharp intuition, and dark humor. While he serves as a good listener and mentor, he is also easily provoked and not always endearing. The novel shines a light on his perseverance, resourcefulness, and determination. Stacey, Mike's wife, has a smaller yet significant role, enhancing the story’s depth. The well-developed characters and their interactions enrich the narrative.
The novel is a fast-paced, gripping read that immerses readers in the characters' lives through its atmospheric writing style.

The portrayal of rural northern Maine is exceptional, immersing readers in the captivating atmosphere of the north woods. The detailed and vivid world-building effectively transports us into this enchanting setting.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a riveting crime thriller that combines intense action, suspense, and strong characterization with immersive world-building. Despite a few predictable moments and unresolved loose ends, the novel is engaging, atmospheric, and fast-paced. It’s a compelling stand-alone read for fans of crime thrillers and wilderness adventures.

review: The book was a fast-paced, well-crafted thriller that kept me engaged from start to finish. Its suspenseful plot was filled with dangerous situations and tension-filled scenes that maintained my interest throughout. With plenty of unexpected twists, I was always eager to see what would happen next. The conclusion was both satisfying and exhilarating.

Mike Bowditch is a compelling protagonist, and I enjoyed delving into his thought process and strategic planning. The supporting cast—particularly his wife, an EMT with invaluable medical knowledge, his father-in-law Charley, and Josie Johnson—added depth and intensity to the narrative. The relationship between Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady was especially intriguing, with their secrets keeping me guessing throughout.

The vivid descriptions of Maine’s unique and challenging landscape enriched the story, with the secluded setting enhancing my enjoyment. This atmosphere of isolation and tension perfectly complemented the plot.

The mystery of Mark Redmond’s disappearance and his daughter Cady was utterly captivating. The secrets they harbored were so sensitive that they resorted to extreme measures to protect them. As the tension escalated, I eagerly anticipated how Mike would unravel the truth and piece together the puzzle.
conclusion: Pitch Dark by the author is an action-packed thriller that delivers on all fronts—suspense, atmosphere, and character depth. As my first introduction to the series, it left me eager to explore more of the stories. The fast-paced plot, vivid setting, and satisfying conclusion make it a highly recommended read for fans of thrillers.

review: The story follows Mike Bowditch, a Maine Game Warden Investigator, who becomes embroiled in a mysterious case involving a missing stranger and a reclusive man living deep in the woods. This man is constructing a log cabin for an acquaintance of Mike’s wife and father-in-law, raising suspicions, especially since he lives with his young daughter, who is never seen in town or at school. The narrative propels the reader into a thrilling and perilous chase through the northern Maine woods and into Canada. Fast-paced and engrossing, the novel offers ample action that keeps readers engaged. Its unique focus on a game warden investigator provides a refreshing perspective on the police procedural genre.

Mike Bowditch stands out as a compelling protagonist. Persistent and generally respectful of the rules, he also exhibits a brash streak that can be off-putting to others. His sense of humor adds depth to his character, enhancing his relatability and engagement.
The author masterfully establishes a vivid sense of place and tension, immersing readers in the rugged and foreboding landscape of northern Maine.
conclusion: This is a fast-paced, atmospheric thriller with a unique premise and a compelling protagonist. The story is engaging, the setting is vividly portrayed, and the action keeps you hooked. Despite some over-the-top moments, it’s a highly enjoyable read that works well as a standalone.

As a local, he provides an authentic perspective that resonates with readers, especially those of us living in New England. I particularly enjoyed the references to local birds and game, which reflect my own experiences during our annual vacations to Maine’s stunning southern and mid coasts. It's truly a beautiful region.
I loved it! I started in the middle and quickly read through the entire series. I can't wait for the next installment!

review: The story begins with a younger warden's urgent call, reporting a missing man while searching for a man and his teenage daughter who have vanished off the grid. The ensuing chase unfolds in harsh conditions, with gunfire and real danger heightening the tension. This frantic pursuit through unforgiving terrain makes for an exhilarating addition to the series. Despite the breakneck speed, hints of mystery surrounding the true identities of Redmond and his daughter keep readers engaged.

I find Mike Bowditch to be a deeply flawed character. He is often belligerent and insensitive, with clumsy questioning techniques that frequently put people on the defensive. This unchanging behavior has been evident since his debut in *The Poacher’s Son*, where he was still a rookie game warden, and he appears to have learned little since then. Although he acknowledges advice from his father-in-law, Charlie, it doesn’t seem to have made a difference. Nonetheless, Bowditch's relentless nature makes him an interesting character to read about. His tenacity and ingenuity in the face of adversity render him a protagonist worthy of following.
Pitch Dark offers a breathtaking exploration of Maine's most remarkable landscapes. Its atmospheric and dynamic setting fully immerses the reader.

In his journey, Mike is determined to uncover the true identities of Redmond and his daughter, along with the reasons behind their flight. The mystery surrounding them unfolds, leading to unexpected twists as the story progresses. The tension escalates when Mike encounters a bounty hunter also pursuing Redmond. Instead of collaborating, their conflicting interests create further complications, adding depth to the narrative.
conclusion: Despite my dislike for Mike Bowditch’s personality and methods, I remain devoted to the storytelling due to his relentless nature and the well-crafted mysteries. Pitch Dark is an atmospheric, energetic, and thoroughly entertaining entry that keeps you hooked with its breathless pace and intriguing mystery. The stunning portrayal of Maine’s locales and the complex chase make it a standout thriller, even for newcomers.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**

- **Character Development (Mike Bowditch):**
   - I don’t like Mike Bowditch. He’s belligerent, insensitive, and his questioning methods are clumsy and prone to put people on the defensive. This has been consistent since book 1 (The Poacher’s Son) when he was still a rookie game warden, and it seems he’s learned nothing since. He acknowledges advice from Charlie, his father-in-law, but it doesn’t seem to have helped.
   - Despite his flaws, Mike Bowditch is relentless, and this quality makes him worth reading about. His tenacity and ingenuity when faced with adversity make him a protagonist worth following.

- **Plot and Pacing:**
   - The story starts with a call from a younger warden who fears a man has gone missing while looking for a man and his teenage daughter who have gone off the grid. The chase is on, with conditions being poor, guns involved, and the danger being real.
   - The desperate chase through unforgiving terrain, all of which takes place at breakneck speed, ensures that this is a thoroughly entertaining entry in the series. The chase is done at a breathless pace, yet along the way, we’re lured in by the suggestion that mystery lies over the real identity and nature of Redmond and his daughter.

- **Setting and Atmosphere:**
   - Pitch Dark provides a stunning portrait of Maine’s most spectacular locales. The atmospheric and energetic setting draws you in completely.

- **Mystery and Suspense:**
   - Along the way, Mike is constantly trying to work out who Redmond and his daughter really are, why they’re running, and what they’re running from. The mystery over their real identity and nature requires answering and is where the shocks and surprises lie at the end.
   - The story is made even more interesting when Mike crosses paths with a bounty hunter who is also on Redmond’s trail. Rather than joining forces, they tend to butt heads, making a complicated situation even more complicated.

- **Series Continuity and Standalone Potential:**
   - We’re now 15 books deep into the series, but it’s definitely possible to enjoy this as a standalone thriller. Paul Doiron provides enough background information to ensure newcomers to the series understand the background of character relationships and past events.

**Conclusion:**
Despite my dislike for Mike Bowditch’s personality and methods, I remain devoted to this series due to his relentless nature and the well-crafted mysteries. Pitch Dark is an atmospheric, energetic, and thoroughly entertaining entry that keeps you hooked with its breathless pace and intriguing mystery. The stunning portrayal of Maine’s locales and the complex chase make it a standout thriller, even for newcomers to the series.

**Rating Scores:**
{No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.}

review: This novel is a thrilling page-turner with a fast-paced storyline. It follows Mike Bowditch, his father-in-law, and a bush pilot as they witness a murder and find themselves taken captive. After Mike escapes, he must navigate the perilous Maine wilderness, unarmed, in pursuit of a mysterious fugitive. The tension escalates as he contends with both the killer's superior skills and the dangers of the rugged environment, featuring deadfalls and swollen streams.

Set against the backdrop of the dense, wind-swept Maine forest, the story unfolds in a landscape teeming with predators. This wilderness acts as both a physical and metaphorical stalking ground for danger, enriching the atmosphere. The author, a native Mainer and seasoned outdoorsman, infuses the narrative with authenticity, particularly in his depiction of survival and the natural world. This genuine portrayal enhances the story's voice, making it both immersive and believable.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a thrilling addition, offering a gripping plot, an immersive setting, and an authentic voice that readers will appreciate. The dangerous wilderness and the killer's cunning make for a tense and unforgettable read.

review: This novel is both absorbing and suspenseful, featuring a plot that captivates readers from start to finish. The story follows Game Warden Investigator Mike Bowditch as he embarks on a perilous quest to locate a missing man along with a father-daughter duo in the rugged wilderness of Maine and Canada. The narrative is filled with unexpected twists and turns that enhance the suspense and maintain unpredictability. While some elements of the plot may seem implausible, these are overshadowed by the overall strengths of the story. The balance between suspense and realism is effectively maintained, ensuring that the more outlandish aspects do not significantly detract from the overall enjoyment.

In this story, the protagonist Mike Bowditch stands out as a determined and resourceful investigator. His relationships with key figures like his father-in-law, Charley Stevens, and family friend Josie Johnson enrich the narrative. The antagonists, Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady, are equally compelling, their enigmatic actions propelling the plot forward.

The author's writing is commended for its clarity and enjoyment, with a smooth narrative that keeps readers engaged. Their ability to combine a fast pace with clear expression stands out as a notable strength.

The author’s expertise shines through in the detailed descriptions of bush plane flying, log cabin construction, maple syrup production, law enforcement procedures, and North Woods flora and fauna. This specificity lends the story an authentic and immersive quality, enhancing the overall reading experience.
conclusion: The author’s *Pitch Dark* is a gripping and well-crafted mystery/thriller that combines suspense, authentic detail, and strong character development. Despite some minor plot elements that stretch believability, the novel is a highly enjoyable read, thanks to the author's engaging writing style and ability to bring the North Woods setting to life.

review: The story opens with Mike receiving a distress call from a game warden in a remote area, setting off a missing person investigation. The plot quickly intensifies as Mike and Charlie delve into the disappearance of Josie, a helicopter pilot, along with Mark Redmond and his 12-year-old daughter, Cady. The narrative is action-packed, blending suspense, physical challenges, and clever twists. The pacing is expertly balanced, maintaining my engagement as the stakes escalate and the situation grows more perilous. Several unexpected twists keep me guessing and add depth to the plot. The ending features a cliffhanger and intriguing developments that leave me eagerly anticipating the next installment.

This story showcases engaging characters, especially Mike Bowditch, the Maine game warden investigator who takes center stage. His relationships with his wife Stacey, now an EMT, and her father, retired game warden Charlie Stevens, enrich the narrative. Charlie acts as a mentor and father figure to Mike, though in this installment, Mike is the primary focus, with Charlie assuming a crucial but secondary role and Stacey appearing minimally.

The remote, rugged landscape of Maine, marked by limited cell phone access and challenging terrain, heightens the story's tension and realism. The journey to an even more isolated sugar mill amplifies the sense of danger and seclusion.
I thoroughly enjoyed this installment and am grateful for the opportunity to read it. Mike Bowditch's adventures continue to be a favorite of mine, and I eagerly await the release of the next book.
conclusion: This installment delivers another thrilling, action-packed adventure with engaging characters and a well-crafted plot. The remote Maine setting, clever twists, and high-stakes situations keep me hooked, while the cliffhanger ending ensures anticipation for the next book.

review: The plot is tense and well-crafted, but I encountered a significant plot hole at 35% that I couldn’t overlook. The main character, a trained law enforcement officer, pursues a heavily armed fugitive armed only with a pair of scissors and a dull axe, which feels unrealistic and frustrating. Despite being inherently risk-averse, the decision to confront a better-equipped opponent alone reflects poor judgment. The pilot’s murder doesn’t warrant such a reckless charge into a disadvantageous situation, especially since the victim is already dead. Introducing a ticking clock, such as a hostage scenario, and equipping the MC with at least one firearm could have made the situation more believable.

The protagonist is an arrogant bloodhound, exhibiting traits that verge on toxic masculinity disguised as Mythic Heroism. The narrative perpetuates the Mythic Alpha Male trope, where the hero triumphs against seemingly insurmountable odds, which feels unrealistic and disconnected from rational behavior. This portrayal is both triggering and exhausting, particularly in light of contemporary discussions surrounding masculinity and heroism. By the 35% mark, there is little evidence that the protagonist examines his own toxic behavior beyond surface-level acknowledgments.

The author’s expertise in the setting—encompassing law enforcement in the remote northeast, cabin construction, and survival skills—adds significant depth to the story. Their diligent research is commendable and elevates the overall rating, even though I had some personal concerns regarding the plot and characterization.

The plot holes and characterization issues hindered my ability to suspend disbelief, causing me to stop reading past 35%. I was disheartened by the continuation of the Mythic Alpha Male narrative and what it signifies about societal expectations. While I recognize that many readers appreciate this trope, I find it neither relatable nor entertaining.
conclusion: Despite the author’s impressive research and tense writing, the unrealistic plot hole and the perpetuation of the Mythic Alpha Male trope made it difficult for me to continue reading. While I respect the effort put into the story, the characterization and narrative choices didn’t resonate with me personally, leading me to stop at 35%.
reformatted_ori_review:

   - The decision to go alone against a better-prepared opponent, despite being risk-averse by nature, seems like a massive lack of judgment.  
   - The murder of the pilot doesn’t justify charging into such a disadvantageous situation, as the victim is already dead.  
   - A potential fix could have been introducing a ticking clock (e.g., a hostage situation) and equipping the MC with at least one gun to make the scenario more believable.  

- **Characterization and Toxic Masculinity:**  
   - The MC is described as an arrogant bloodhound, but his actions go beyond arrogance into what feels like toxic masculinity masked as Mythic Heroism.  
   - The perpetuation of the Mythic Alpha Male narrative, where the hero defies impossible odds, feels unrealistic and disconnected from how a sane person would act.

   - I feel discouraged by the perpetuation of the Mythic Alpha Male narrative and what it reveals about societal expectations.

**Conclusion:**  
Despite the author’s impressive research and tense writing, the unrealistic plot hole and the perpetuation of the Mythic Alpha Male trope made it difficult for me to continue reading. review: The novel reads like a 300-page chase scene, ultimately becoming monotonous and lacking depth. The frequent shifts between rain and mist during the pursuit strain believability, particularly as the protagonist, Mike Bowditch, consistently outruns or outmaneuvers his prey in these challenging conditions.

Mike Bowditch is an unlikable and overly aggressive character whose behavior lacks clear justification. His self-absorption is particularly evident in a scene where he insists on being called "Warden" instead of "Ranger" while addressing a bleeding man, which feels both petty and insensitive.
The implausibility of several events in the story, especially the protagonist's actions and the environmental conditions, undermines its overall realism.

The book fell short of expectations, particularly when compared to the author's previous works. By the end, I found myself wishing for the protagonist's demise, highlighting a significant disconnect with both the character and the story.
conclusion: This installment was disappointing, primarily due to its repetitive plot, unrealistic scenarios, and an unlikeable protagonist. The lack of depth and believability made it a frustrating read, leading to the decision to stop following the author’s work.

review: In this gripping tale, Josie buys land and enlists the help of skilled builder Mark Redmond to construct her dream cabin, offering him privacy to homeschool his daughter, Cady, in return. However, Game Warden Mike Bowditch investigates unsettling rumors about Redmond and his daughter, which leads him into a harrowing ordeal after he witnesses a murder and is taken captive. The narrative evolves into a tense cat-and-mouse chase through the Maine wilderness, as Mike races against time to rescue Redmond and Cady from a formidable and dangerous foe.

Mike Bowditch is an intense and intuitive investigator whose humor and gruff demeanor can occasionally make him seem less likable. The well-developed characters possess depth and intrigue, making them compelling. The supporting characters further enrich the narrative, adding layers to the story.

The author’s writing is sharp and suspenseful, weaving a complex, twisty plot that keeps readers on the edge of their seats. The atmospheric details vividly immerse readers in the Maine setting, making them feel like active participants in the investigation. The layered plot unfolds with a slow-burn buildup, culminating in a brilliantly executed ending.

This novel is a masterful atmospheric thriller that captivates with its dark, disturbing, and unpredictable storyline. From start to finish, it maintains a tense atmosphere and delivers edge-of-your-seat action, keeping readers fully engaged.
conclusion: The author’s *Pitch Dark* is a gripping novel that offers a standalone experience with a well-crafted plot, compelling characters, and a suspenseful atmosphere. The combination of sharp writing, intricate storytelling, and excellent narration makes this a must-read for thriller fans.

The detective’s actions are entirely plausible, making him a relatable and believable protagonist. His attempts to gain the trust of the fugitive and his daughter before events unravel add depth to his character.

conclusion: This is a well-crafted and realistic thriller with a strong sense of place and believable characters. Fans of *These Silent Woods* will likely enjoy this novel for its tense atmosphere, grounded storytelling, and compelling cat-and-mouse dynamic.

review: In this intriguing narrative, Mike learns of an armed man with a substantial amount of cash who is inquiring about a man and his daughter living in a tent while constructing a log cabin for Josie Johnson. The mysterious man, who rented an ATV, has disappeared without a trace. With the area battered by relentless storms, Mike decides to investigate the builder, warn him about the looming threat, and ensure that the ATV renter hasn't met an unfortunate fate. Josie offers to fly Mike and his father-in-law in her helicopter to the cabin site, setting the stage for a bizarre and perilous adventure.
Mike may have finally found his match in builder Mark Redmon, who is not who he seems.
This is undoubtedly a gripping thriller that kept me hooked from start to finish.
conclusion: This novel is a thrilling addition, with a gripping plot, intense character dynamics, and excellent pacing. It stands out as the best so far and is an unputdownable read.

The man with the cash rented an ATV and never returned it. The area has been hit with storm after storm, and Mike decides to check out the builder, warn him about the man searching for him, and see if the man on the ATV has come to harm. review: My main issue with the book was that the first 20-25% felt aimless, leading me to double-check the synopsis to ensure I was reading the right story. However, once the plot began to unfold, it became quite engaging.

The main character comes across as overly perfect and excessively fortunate, often feeling overpowered. He frequently makes assumptions based on the occupations of other men, and it's only due to the author's influence that he consistently ends up being correct.

While this book isn't my usual cup of tea, it's not without merit. I can easily see it appealing to my father-in-law or other middle-aged men, especially once the action takes off. It embodies the quintessential "Dad Book" with plenty of chases, high-stakes scenarios, explosions, fire, and rugged characters navigating the wilderness. The story features clever problem-solving and niche knowledge that helps them escape dire situations. Overall, it’s an entertaining read for its target audience.
conclusion: While the book had a slow start and the main character felt overly perfect, it eventually delivered on action and excitement, making it a solid choice for its target audience. The audiobook narration was serviceable but could have been more engaging.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Standalone Readability:**  
  This is the first book I've read in the series, but it honestly reads enough like a standalone that it was perfectly fine.  

- **Pacing and Plot Development:**  
  My biggest complaint is that the first 20-25% of the book felt like the characters were faffing about. I had to double-check the synopsis to make sure I was reading the right book because it seemed so unrelated and unwilling to start the actual plot. However, once the plot picked up, it was fairly solid.  

- **Genre and Tone:**  
  This is peak Dad Book. There's (eventually) a lot of chases and high-octane situations. There are explosions, fires, gruff men making their way through the wilderness, and using niche knowledge to get out of impossible situations.  

- **Characterization:**  
  The main character is a little too perfect, a little too lucky, and a little too generally overpowered. He makes a lot of assumptions, often based on the jobs of other men, and it's only because of the author that he always turns out to be right.  

- **Target Audience:**  
  This isn't a bad book, despite very much not being my kind of read. I could easily hand it over to my father-in-law or other middle-aged men I know and feel like it will keep them sufficiently entertained once the action picks up.  

- **Audiobook Performance:**  
  The standard male narrator did a decent job. He could've injected just a wee bit more emotion or personality, but overall, his performance was average.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the book had a slow start and the main character felt overly perfect, it eventually delivered on action and excitement, making it a solid choice for its target audience. The audiobook narration was serviceable but could have been more engaging.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

In this gripping story, the protagonist Mike Bowditch, a game warden, leads the investigation into the mysterious disappearance of Hammond Pratt. As he delves deeper, his growing suspicion of cabin builder Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady intensifies the narrative. The characters are skillfully woven into the plot, enhancing the story’s suspense and intrigue.

The book's setting is one of its strongest aspects, situated in the remote, shadowy woods of Maine extending into Canada. This isolated and atmospheric backdrop heightens the tension and resonates with the reader's inherent fear of being lost or abandoned in a secluded forest.

I found the story deeply engaging, describing it as a tense adventure that resonated with my personal fears. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time, demonstrating a high level of emotional investment and excitement.

review: The story follows Mike Bowditch, a Warden Investigator from Maine, who is alerted to a missing man in the Prentiss Pond area. This man had been asking about the enigmatic father-daughter pair, Mark and Cady Redmond. Accompanied by his father-in-law Charley Stevens and friend Josie Jonson, Mike heads to Prentiss Pond to investigate. The plot intensifies when Mike's suspicions about Mark Redmond are validated, igniting a thrilling chase through the Maine wilderness as Mark and Cady attempt to escape to the Canadian border. The pacing is excellent, keeping me engaged with a suspenseful narrative that highlights Mike's tracking skills, adding to the overall tension and excitement.

Mike Bowditch continues to be a compelling protagonist, possessing self-awareness and a strong sense of justice. The vivid descriptions of the Maine wilderness and the engaging characters enhance the narrative. However, I was disappointed by the limited presence of Stacy, Mike’s wife. Considering their recent marriage, I anticipated more scenes showcasing their relationship.
conclusion: Overall, this is a great addition. The plot is gripping, the characters are well-developed, and the descriptions of the Maine wilderness are immersive. While I missed seeing more of Stacy, the story remains highly enjoyable and satisfying.

The man had been inquiring about Mark and Cady Redmond, a secretive father-daughter duo. Mike, along with his father-in-law Charley Stevens and their friend Josie Jonson, flies to Prentiss Pond to investigate. The plot takes a thrilling turn when Mike’s suspicions about Mark Redmond are confirmed, leading to a suspenseful chase through the Maine wilderness as Mark and Cady attempt to flee to the Canadian border.

  Mike is a likable protagonist, and his relationships with his family and co-workers are well-developed. His interactions with his father-in-law and a family friend add depth to the narrative. The dynamics between the characters feel authentic and contribute to the story's richness.  

- **Series Continuity and Standalone Appeal:**  
  While this book is part of a series featuring Mike, it works well as a standalone. The author provides sufficient backstory, making it easy for new readers to understand the characters and their histories without needing to read the previous books.  

- **Pacing and Engagement:**  
  The story is fast-paced and gripping, with enough twists and turns to maintain suspense. The blend of mystery, action, and survival elements ensures that readers remain invested throughout.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Pitch Dark* is an engaging and well-crafted mystery-thriller that combines a compelling plot, relatable characters, and a fast-paced narrative. The author successfully balances action and character development, making it an enjoyable read for both new and returning fans of the series.  

**Rating Scores:**  
4 stars.

review: The ending skillfully sidesteps false cliffhangers while placing Bowditch at a crucial turning point, heightening anticipation for future developments. Set against the rugged and atmospheric landscape of northern Maine, the narrative captures the essence of its remote backdrop. Central to the plot is Bowditch's relentless quest for justice, which occasionally edges into tunnel vision.

Mike Bowditch, the protagonist, is newly married, yet his adventurous spirit remains undiminished. As he pursues a violent wilderness savant and his daughter, Bowditch displays extraordinary determination, though it occasionally teeters on the edge of believability. In this installment, his character adopts a tougher demeanor, particularly evident in his steadfast commitment to the law — he arrests a well-meaning couple that interferes with his quest. This decision inadvertently sparks an international crisis, highlighting his intense focus on his personal sense of right and wrong. By the end of the novel, Bowditch faces a career crossroads, leaving his professional future hanging in the balance.
The story adopts a visceral and gritty tone, featuring grisly violence, including scenes with children. This lends the novel a harsher edge compared to its predecessors.
The novel delves into themes of morality, justice, and the repercussions of relentless determination.
The novel is fast-paced and utterly engaging; I finished it in just two days, a testament to its gripping nature.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a thrilling addition, delivering a fast-paced, action-packed narrative with a harder edge. While Bowditch’s superhuman persistence can stretch believability, his character development and the novel’s exploration of justice and morality make it a compelling read. The visceral violence and gritty tone may not be for everyone, but fans will appreciate the high stakes and the setup for future developments.

review: The plot centers on a pre-teen girl trained for criminal activities, leading to a series of murders. A Maine game warden becomes involved following the murder of a bush pilot, sparking a pursuit of the killers. The story escalates with the entrance of a private investigator who finds himself increasingly entangled in the case as more murders unfold. The narrative also explores illegal border crossings, adding complexity and tension, particularly with the Canadian Mounties' disdain for the situation. Action-packed sequences, including boat chases, ATV pursuits, and helicopter scenes, maintain an exhilarating pace, complemented by numerous gun battles and cold-water events. The conclusion is thrilling, leaving the Canadian Mounties dissatisfied as they ultimately fail to apprehend their target.

The story features a troubled family, a resolute Maine game warden, a clever private investigator, and disgruntled Canadian Mounties. The survivalist family possesses a notable advantage in the wilderness, rendering them formidable opponents.
The story's setting in a wild, remote area is crucial, highlighting themes of survival and isolation.
This book delves into a dark and unsettling theme, focusing on a dysfunctional family residing off the grid along the Maine-Canadian border.
conclusion: This novel delivers a gripping and dark narrative set in a remote and wild environment. The complex plot, involving a disturbed family and a series of murders, is enriched by the involvement of a game warden and a private investigator. The action-packed sequences and the tension of illegal border crossings keep me engaged until the exciting conclusion. Despite the lack of car chases, the use of boats, ATVs, and helicopters, along with numerous gun battles, ensures a thrilling read. The ending leaves the Canadian Mounties frustrated, adding a layer of realism and unresolved tension.

review: The story opens with a rookie game warden reporting the potential disappearance of Hammond Pratt, who had rented a cabin and an ATV in a secluded area of Maine. Pratt's inquiries about a father and son who recently moved nearby, including offers of money for information, set the stage for an intriguing mystery. The investigation leads Mike and his team to Josie Jonson, a skilled pilot and the godmother of Mike’s wife, who helps them access the remote cabin by helicopter. Upon arrival, they witness a murder and are captured by the father and son, heightening the tension and propelling the narrative forward. The story effectively evolves from a missing person case into a gripping confrontation, with the team's capture marking a pivotal moment that intensifies the plot and engages the reader.

Mike Bowditch, the protagonist and a Maine game warden investigator, navigates a pivotal moment in his life marked by his recent marriage and the potential of impending fatherhood. The introduction of his father-in-law, Charles Stevens, a retired warden, enriches the narrative and forges connections between Mike and other central characters, such as Josie Jonson.
The vividly described setting, marked by the rainy season that renders trails nearly impassable, enhances the tension and realism of the plot.
conclusion: This latest Mike Bowditch novel combines a richly developed protagonist with a gripping plot set in the rugged wilderness of Maine. The personal stakes for Mike, the atmospheric setting, and the escalating suspense make for a compelling read. The story’s pacing keeps me engaged, especially as the mystery deepens and the danger intensifies.

review: In this story, Mike, the protagonist, often comes across as insufferable due to his self-righteousness. His rigid moral stance can be off-putting, and he would benefit from being more forgiving. In contrast, Craig Johnson's protagonist, Longmire, is more lenient and understanding, making him a more relatable character. Bowditch would do well to adopt Longmire's approach.
conclusion: While I find the protagonist, Mike, to be overly righteous and insufferable at times, I still consider this novel to be the author's best work to date. I draw a comparison to Craig Johnson's protagonist, Longmire, suggesting that Mike could benefit from a more lenient and understanding demeanor.

review: The story follows rookie game warden Brandon Barstow and seasoned investigator Mike Bowditch as they tackle a mysterious disappearance in Maine's North Woods. The intrigue deepens with the arrival of Hammond Pratt, who is seeking information about a reclusive man, Mark Redmond, and his daughter, Cady. The narrative is rich with twists, red herrings, and numerous suspects, ensuring that readers remain engaged and guessing until the very end. The author expertly maintains a gripping pace, crafting well-developed characters and a plot that keeps readers on the edge of their seats.

Mike Bowditch is a skilled investigator, though his flaws—such as a tendency to jump to conclusions and a quick temper—often complicate his work. His personal life adds depth to his character, particularly as he navigates the prospect of fatherhood, shaped by his own troubled childhood. In contrast, Mark Redmond is a devoted father, yet his choice to raise his daughter in near seclusion raises intriguing questions about his true nature.
The story effectively caters to new readers while simultaneously satisfying long-time fans.

The Maine wilderness provides a vivid and immersive backdrop that heightens the story's tension and danger. The harsh weather and remote locations intensify the suspense and test the characters' survival skills.
The novel delves into themes of trust, protection, and the moral complexities of distinguishing between the innocent and the guilty.
Mike's internal struggle with fatherhood and his past enriches the narrative with emotional depth.
conclusion: Pitch Dark is a compelling mystery that combines a well-crafted plot, complex characters, and a richly detailed setting. The novel’s twists and emotional depth make it an engrossing read, suitable for both new readers and fans alike. The story’s exploration of moral dilemmas and personal growth adds layers to the narrative, making it a standout addition.

review: The story opens with game warden investigator Mike Bowditch searching for a missing man named Pratt, who had been asking about a stranger and his young daughter. The plot swiftly evolves into a tense manhunt for a dangerous fugitive. With its urgent pacing and vivid descriptions, I was immersed in the chilling, dark, and damp atmosphere. The conclusion offers a sense of resolution but leaves some questions unanswered, including the outcome of Stacey’s pregnancy test, creating anticipation for future installments.

Mike Bowditch serves as a complex and relatable protagonist. Despite his experience, he grapples with uncertainty and questions whether he truly has all the facts. His internal conflicts, particularly his ambivalence about impending fatherhood, add depth to his character. Well-developed supporting characters like Charley Stevens and Josie Jonson enhance the narrative significantly. Meanwhile, Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady bring an intriguing air of mystery that keeps readers guessing.

The author's keen attention to detail and sense of urgency create an immersive and engaging narrative. The vivid descriptions of the North Woods of Maine stand out, enhancing the story's realism. While the inclusion of gun violence and some foul language may be unsettling, these elements serve to reinforce the gritty tone of the novel.

The novel delves into themes of family, responsibility, and moral ambiguity. Mike's reflections on his father and his own potential as a father bring emotional depth to the narrative. The resolution is satisfying, if not conventionally happy, which suits the story's context.

The mystery is skillfully crafted, with clues thoughtfully woven throughout the narrative. Upon reflection, I noted that some hints were subtle and easily overlooked, which enhanced the overall intrigue.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a gripping and immersive mystery that combines rugged adventure with emotional depth. The author’s vivid writing and well-developed characters make this a standout read, even for those new to the author. While the resolution is bittersweet, it feels authentic and satisfying. Fans of mysteries and outdoor adventures will find this novel to be a thrilling ride.

review: This story follows Mike, who becomes increasingly suspicious of Mark and his daughter Cady, who live off the grid. His unease escalates when he, Charley, and Josie are drugged and tied to a tree, resulting in Josie’s tragic death. The plot thickens as Mike uncovers that a couple is on the run from Canadian authorities, suspected of murdering one of their mothers. Teaming up with a bounty hunter to track them down, Mike faces unexpected challenges, including his own arrest by the Canadian Mounties. The narrative culminates in Mike's return home, where he learns that Stacy is pregnant, forcing him to reflect on fatherhood and his future. The story maintains a steady pace and includes moments of high tension, particularly during the drugging and the confrontation with the couple. The plot twists, such as Mike’s arrest and the revelation of a key character's true identity, effectively keep the reader engaged and invested in the outcome.

Mike is a determined and resourceful character, motivated by a strong sense of justice and concern for others. His personal struggles, particularly his relationship with Stacy and the challenges of impending fatherhood, add depth to his character. A skilled woodsman and marksman, Mike also harbors a mysterious and dangerous past. His daughter, Chloé (Cady), is equally proficient with firearms, which enriches their dynamic. Supporting characters like Charley, Josie, and the bounty hunter are essential in advancing the plot and illuminating Mike’s relationships and challenges.
The off-the-grid setting and wilderness backdrop heighten the story's suspense and danger. Vivid descriptions of the cabin, the surrounding woods, and the chase scenes create an immersive experience.

This story delves into themes of justice, survival, and the intricacies of human relationships. The tragic death of Josie drives feelings of guilt and a fierce determination to seek justice, evoking deep emotional responses. Additionally, the subplot involving Stacy’s pregnancy and Mike’s reflections on fatherhood introduces a layer of introspection and personal growth, enhancing the story's emotional depth and relatability.
conclusion: This novel is a gripping tale of suspense, justice, and personal growth. The intricate plot, well-developed characters, and emotional depth make it a compelling read. The unexpected twists and the exploration of themes like fatherhood and survival leave a lasting impact.

review: The latest installment showcases the author's creativity and ability to keep readers engaged over time. While recent books have been gripping, the overall experience has been somewhat inconsistent. Book 13 was one of the weaker entries, but the following installment showed improvement. In Book 15, elements both strengthened and weakened the narrative. The first half was captivating, featuring a mysterious and formidable adversary, along with beautifully crafted mountain scenes that highlighted the author's talent for vivid descriptions. However, the second half fell short, with a chase that lacked the expected tension and some contrived moments where other characters conveniently resolved plot issues. The repetitive structure of Mike catching, losing, escaping from, and recapturing his quarry initially worked but ultimately lost its tension and became less engaging by the end.

Mike Bowditch's character development has been a notable strength in the series, yet this installment sees him regress into the reckless behavior of earlier books. While the narrative recognizes this recklessness, some actions—such as navigating a sinking boat onto a frigid lake with a critically injured passenger—stretch credibility and feel unrealistic.
conclusion: This 15th installment is a mixed bag. While the first half is captivating and showcases the author's strengths in setting and detail, the second half falters with a less engaging chase and some unrealistic character decisions. The story has had its ups and downs, and this book reflects that trend. However, I remain a loyal fan, hopeful for more adventures and fresh ideas in the future.

review: The story opens with Mike investigating the disappearance of Ammon Pratt, who was looking into Mark Redmond. This is the 15th installment in the series, with several additional side stories. The protagonist, Mike Bowditch, has recently married Stacey Stevens, the daughter of his mentor, Charlie. His choice to chase the Renauds into Canada without proper clearance exemplifies his independent nature, leading to perilous situations.

This book is masterfully crafted and captivating, meeting the high standards I’ve come to expect from this author. After reading ten of their works, I can confidently say that each one has been a delight.
conclusion: This latest installment is a compelling and well-crafted story that continues to deliver the suspense and character depth I’ve come to love. It’s a worthy addition and a highly enjoyable read.

review: The story begins with a seemingly simple injury that rapidly transforms into a life-or-death struggle, keeping the suspense high throughout. The fast-paced narrative makes it hard to put the book down, especially as Mike pursues the antagonist alone, which sustains a relentless momentum. Additionally, the remote and harsh setting of Northern Maine heightens the tension and urgency of the plot.

The absence of Stacey enhanced the narrative for me, as I favored the dynamic between Mike and Dani. While Charley is a beloved character, Mike's solo efforts created a more streamlined and intense storyline. Josie's presence added depth to the team dynamic, yet the focus remained on Mike's individual journey.

The inclusion of French names and multi-word phrases, such as L'Auberge Lac Portage and Saint-Georges-de-Beauce, added authenticity to the setting, though they could be difficult to read and pronounce at times, momentarily slowing the pace. Nevertheless, this did not diminish my overall enjoyment of the story.

The chilly, damp, and muddy landscapes of Northern Maine provided a vivid backdrop for the story. While the use of French names and places near the Canadian border added authenticity, it occasionally interrupted the reading flow for me as an American reader.
I absolutely loved this book; it has become one of my favorites. The fast-paced action and suspenseful plot truly set it apart.
conclusion: This book is a thrilling, fast-paced read, with a gripping plot, well-executed character dynamics, and an immersive setting. While the French names and phrases occasionally slowed my reading, they didn’t diminish my overall enjoyment. It’s a 10/10 for me and ranks among my favorites.

review: The plot follows game warden Bowditch, who unwittingly becomes embroiled in an international fugitive manhunt. It's a dark, disturbing, and emotionally charged narrative, filled with revelations that even surprised a seasoned thriller enthusiast like me. Despite unfolding over a brief time frame, the story is packed with harrowing events, including murder and kidnapping, and features unexpected twists at every turn. While some scenarios may stretch believability, it's fiction, after all. The book concludes without a cliffhanger, effectively setting the stage for the next chapter in the warden's personal and professional journey. The characters are compelling, leaving readers eager for the next installment.

The author masterfully captures the essence of Maine's residents, showcasing their resilience, political views, stubbornness, and unique way of life. The vivid portrayal of the setting enhances the narrative, and after following Mike’s campaign through the rugged forests, lakes, and mountains, I now feel equipped to find a perfect hiding spot if I ever need to escape.
At its core, the plot explores the extraordinary lengths a parent will go to protect their child. The thought-provoking themes and surprising outcomes will leave you astounded.

I discovered this story late and missed most of the earlier installments, but now that I’ve found it, I'm completely hooked. The unique characters, setting, and premise make it captivating, and I’ve thoroughly enjoyed the few books I've read so far.
conclusion: This is a gripping, emotionally charged thriller with a unique setting and well-crafted characters. The plot is intense and thought-provoking, with themes that resonate deeply. While some events may stretch believability, the story’s emotional core and vivid portrayal of Maine make it a standout read.

You get a sense of their resilience, politics, stubbornness, fortitude, and a way of life particular to the place. The setting itself is vividly portrayed, and after following Mike’s campaign through the rugged forests, lakes, and mountain ranges, I now feel like I know where to hide if I ever need to escape.

  The heart of the plot highlights the lengths and depths a parent will go to in order to protect their child. The themes are thought-provoking, and the outcomes will leave you blown away.

This is a gripping, emotionally charged thriller with a unique setting and well-crafted characters. The plot is intense and thought-provoking, with themes that resonate deeply. review: This story follows a missing person case that rapidly evolves into a perilous manhunt. The intricate plot centers on tracking criminals, although Mike initially misjudges their true nature. The introduction of a private investigator adds depth, but Mike's underestimation of him turns out to be a significant error. The pacing is gripping, with tension escalating as the narrative unfolds.

Mike Bowditch is a complex character, and each book reveals more layers to his persona. His troubled background, which includes a criminal father and a distinctive last name, adds depth, while his recent marriage to Stacey, the daughter of his mentor Charley Stevens, further enhances his character. Throughout the story, Mike's unwavering dedication to his job and the protection of others is evident, though he also takes time to reflect on his shortcomings.

Set against the rugged landscapes of Maine and Canada, the story captures the tension and realism of its harsh environment. This unforgiving backdrop enhances the immersive journey, making the trek through these wild areas feel vivid and engaging.

The story delves into themes of dedication, self-reflection, and the moral complexities of law enforcement. Mike's recognition of his limitations in ensuring people's safety adds a significant layer of introspection to the narrative.

Despite its challenging setting and intricate plot, the book remains both engaging and accessible. The narrative captivates the reader, and Mike Bowditch’s character is strong enough to carry the story forward.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* by the author is a gripping read, offering a complex plot, well-developed characters, and an immersive setting. The story’s intensity and Mike’s personal growth make it a highly engaging read.

review: The story follows Mike as he relentlessly pursues Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady, who have drugged and bound Mike and his father-in-law, Charley. With the added emotional weight of Josie's death, the stakes intensify. Mike crosses into Canada, consciously breaking the law and jeopardizing his career, driven by his conviction that Cady is in grave danger.

Mike Bowditch is a compelling protagonist—relentless and impulsive, yet unwaveringly dedicated to his principles. His experience as a game warden shines through, but he encounters a formidable adversary in Mark Redmond, whose survival skills far exceed his own. Mike's initial assessment of Redmond reveals his quick judgment, but as he later realizes his miscalculation, it adds depth to his character and emphasizes his flaws.

This author ranks among my favorite thriller writers. Their talent for creating gripping, fast-paced narratives with well-developed characters and a vivid sense of place is unparalleled. They consistently deliver exceptional stories.
The vivid imagery of Maine's rain-soaked forests, fallen trees, and swollen rivers immerses readers in an atmospheric backdrop that heightens the story's tension and danger during the chase.
The author's books are always captivating, and this one is no exception. With relentless action and a thrilling chase through Maine's wilderness, it kept me hooked from beginning to end.
conclusion: This novel is a thrilling, action-packed read with a compelling protagonist, a high-stakes chase, and a vividly depicted wilderness setting. The author delivers yet another gripping story that keeps readers on the edge of their seats.

review: The plot is gripping and fast-paced; I finished the audiobook in a single day because I couldn't stop listening. It follows Warden Mike Bowditch as he navigates a tense situation in the Maine woods, where the lines between hunter and prey blur. A man and his daughter are hiding off-grid, their motives shrouded in ambiguity. When the man searching for them goes missing, tension escalates, leading multiple parties to search for each other in the forest. The story is filled with unexpected twists that kept me on the edge of my seat, many of which took me by surprise, enhancing the overall experience.

I thoroughly enjoyed Warden Mike Bowditch as the protagonist. His quick thinking, deep knowledge of the land, and training keep him safe, while his resourcefulness and determination make him a captivating character.

This book encapsulates everything I love in a thriller: excitement, unexpected twists, and a deep connection to nature. Set along the Maine-Quebec border, the vivid descriptions of the woods, storms, rain, cold, mud, and darkness make the setting feel like a character in its own right.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a thrilling, atmospheric novel that combines a gripping plot, a strong sense of place, and a compelling protagonist. The twists and turns kept me hooked, and the narration added to the immersive experience. I’m excited to explore more of this intriguing series.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Series Appeal and Discovery:**  
  I didn’t realize how much I needed the Mike Bowditch series in my life until now. After reading *Pitch Dark* (Book #15 in the series) by Paul Doiron, I was hooked and immediately bought the first book, *Poacher’s Son*.  

- **Genre and Themes:**  
  The book has all the elements I love in a thriller: excitement, twists and turns, and a strong connection to nature. The story is set at the Maine/Quebec border, and the setting itself feels like a character, with its vivid descriptions of the woods, storms, rain, cold, mud, and darkness.  

- **Plot and Pacing:**  
  The plot is gripping and fast-paced. I listened to the audiobook in just one day because I couldn’t stop. The story follows Warden Mike Bowditch as he navigates a tense situation in the Maine woods, where it’s unclear who is the hunter and who is the prey. A man and his daughter are hiding off-grid, and their motives are ambiguous. When the man searching for them goes missing, the tension escalates, and multiple parties are suddenly searching for each other in the woods.  

- **Characterization:**  
  I loved Warden Mike Bowditch as a protagonist. He’s a quick thinker who relies on his knowledge of the land and his training to stay safe. His resourcefulness and determination make him a compelling character.  

- **Twists and Surprises:**  
  The book is full of unexpected twists that kept me on the edge of my seat. I didn’t see many of them coming, which made the experience even more enjoyable.  

- **Narration (Audiobook):**  
  The narration by Henry Leyva added to the atmosphere and enhanced my overall experience. His performance brought the story to life and made it even more immersive.  

- **Recommendation:**  
  I highly recommend *Pitch Dark*. It’s so good that it inspired me to start the series from the beginning with *Poacher’s Son*.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Pitch Dark* is a thrilling, atmospheric novel that combines a gripping plot, a strong sense of place, and a compelling protagonist. The twists and turns kept me hooked, and the narration added to the immersive experience. I’m excited to explore more of the Mike Bowditch series.

review: This novel presents an exhilarating cat-and-mouse chase through the Maine woods, propelling the plot into high gear and sustaining tension until the gratifying conclusion. The story follows a rookie warden who turns to Mike Bowditch for assistance with a missing person case, ultimately unraveling the mystery of an off-the-grid builder and his young daughter. Although the protagonist occasionally makes questionable decisions, the strong storytelling and well-developed characters make these moments easy to overlook, allowing readers to fully enjoy the journey.

Mike Bowditch is a captivating protagonist haunted by his dark past, yet driven to solve crimes and seek justice for victims. The supporting cast, including the rookie warden and the enigmatic builder, is well-developed, enriching the narrative and enhancing the story’s complexity.

The vivid descriptions of the Maine wilderness and the incorporation of local terminology, such as "skidder trails" and "puckerbrush," lend authenticity to the story. As someone familiar with the region, I found the portrayal of the outdoor environment and culture both accurate and enjoyable.
conclusion: This installment of the Mike Bowditch Mysteries delivers a thrilling and immersive experience, with a well-crafted plot, authentic setting, and compelling characters. The audiobook narration adds an extra layer of enjoyment, making it a highly recommended listen for both fans and newcomers alike.

review: This gripping thriller captivates from beginning to end. With its relentless pacing and a race against time to thwart a killer and save an innocent victim, the story is packed with suspense, danger, and unexpected twists that make it impossible to put down.

Josie Jonson, the legendary female pilot, serves as a compelling protagonist, and her interactions with Mark Redmond and his daughter Cady enrich the narrative. Mike Bowditch, the game warden investigator, is a well-crafted character whose suspicions and actions propel much of the plot. The dynamics among the characters, including the killer, are engaging and infuse the story with emotional depth.

The author's writing is captivating and immersive, skillfully building suspense and maintaining high tension throughout the novel. Vivid descriptions and attention to detail bring both the setting and action scenes to life.

review: The plot centers on the search for a missing person, guiding Bowditch and Charlie to a remote location with the assistance of skilled bush pilot Josie. The narrative unfolds with surprising twists, as the characters uncover far more than they anticipated, making for an exhilarating read. The mystery is intricately woven, and divulging further details would spoil the experience, so I will refrain from specifics.

Mike Bowditch, Maine's “warden investigator,” defies the typical forest ranger mold. He resembles a blend of Jack Reacher and Jason Bourne, yet he’s not on the run. The relationship between Bowditch and his retired warden father-in-law, Charlie, enriches the narrative, particularly as they navigate their reluctant involvement in a missing person case. Additionally, the builder and his twelve-year-old daughter are compelling characters shrouded in mystery, contributing to the story's tension and intrigue.

This book is captivating and nearly impossible to set aside. I found myself eagerly turning pages to uncover what happens next. The intense pacing nearly kept me up all night, and if I weren’t 75, I might have lost sleep over it!
conclusion: The author’s *Pitch Dark* is a gripping, fast-paced novel that keeps you hooked from start to finish. With well-developed characters and a compelling mystery, it's a must-read for fans of thrillers and crime fiction. Just be warned: don’t start it too close to bedtime unless you’re prepared to lose sleep!

review: The story follows Mike Bowditch, a Maine game warden, as he investigates a reclusive builder and his 12-year-old daughter. The plot thickens with the disappearance of a YouTuber who alleges that the builder is a fugitive responsible for his wife's murder. As the narrative unfolds, unexpected twists lead to a dramatic and perilous climax. The story poses thought-provoking questions about the daughter's safety and the builder's guilt, keeping readers engaged until the end.

Mike Bowditch is a determined and resourceful protagonist. The enigmatic builder possesses impressive skills, while his intelligent and well-educated daughter stands out despite her isolation. Supporting characters, such as Charley, Mike’s father-in-law, and Josie Jonson, a pilot and friend, enrich the narrative. The inclusion of a YouTuber/bounty hunter introduces an element of unpredictability and conflict.
Set against the stunning wilderness of Maine, the story unfolds in a beautifully crafted log cabin that showcases the builder's artistry and deep connection to nature.
The story delves into themes of isolation, morality, and the complexities of truth, prompting thought-provoking questions about justice, protection, and the essence of danger.
conclusion: This novel is a gripping and suspenseful read, featuring a well-crafted plot, compelling characters, and a richly detailed setting. Fans of the author and C.J. Box will appreciate the twists and turns, as well as the moral dilemmas presented. The audio narration by Henry Leyva further elevates the experience, making it a must-listen for fans.

review: The story kicks off when Mike receives a call about a suspicious, armed man asking about a father and daughter nearby. The man rents an ATV and ventures into the woods, prompting Mike and his father-in-law, Charley, to investigate. Although they don't find the man, they do locate the father-daughter duo, who are using fake identities. After drugging Mike, Charley, and a local pilot, the pair vanishes, sending Mike on a tense chase through harsh, freezing terrain. The suspense is expertly maintained, making it a true page-turner.

Mike Bowditch is a captivating protagonist, and his relationships with Charley and Josey enrich the narrative. Renaud and Chloe serve as intriguing antagonists, though their motivations could benefit from deeper exploration.
The sense of place is vivid and evocative, reminiscent of Peter Heller's style. The isolated, rugged landscape of northern Maine enriches the narrative, adding both depth and tension.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a suspenseful, fast-paced thriller with a strong sense of place and engaging characters. While it didn’t compel me to explore further, it was an enjoyable stand-alone read.

The story introduces Mike Bowditch, a game warden investigator, and is set in the remote northernmost region of Maine, near the Canadian border.

- **Plot and Pacing:**  
  The plot begins when Mike receives a call about a suspicious, armed individual inquiring about a father and daughter in the area. The man rents an ATV and heads into the woods, prompting Mike and his father-in-law, Charley, to investigate. Despite not finding the man, they locate the father-daughter duo, Paul Renaud and Chloe, who are traveling under fake names. After drugging Mike, Charley, and a local pilot named Josey, Paul and Chloe disappear, leading Mike on a tense pursuit through harsh, freezing terrain. The suspense is well-maintained, making it a page-turner.

- **Setting and Atmosphere:**  
  The sense of place is strong and evocative, reminiscent of Peter Heller’s writing. The isolated, rugged landscape of northern Maine adds depth and tension to the story.

- **Characterization:**  
  Mike Bowditch is a compelling protagonist, and his dynamic with Charley and Josey adds layers to the narrative. Paul Renaud and Chloe are intriguing antagonists, though their motivations could have been explored further.

- **Overall Enjoyment and Recommendation:**  
  *Pitch Dark* is what I’d call an “airport book”—a quick, entertaining read perfect for passing time during a flight. While I didn’t enjoy it enough to commit to reading the entire series, it was a solid stand-alone novel.

**Conclusion:**  
*Pitch Dark* is a suspenseful, fast-paced thriller with a strong sense of place and engaging characters. While it didn’t compel me to explore the rest of the series, it was an enjoyable stand-alone read.

The story follows a mysterious man living off the grid with his 12-year-old daughter. A skilled cabin builder, he constructs an impressive log cabin for a friend of Charley. Mike becomes intrigued by the man's enigmatic lifestyle, his absence from the digital world, and the bounty hunter pursuing him and his daughter. His resourcefulness and courage come to the forefront, even as the stakes escalate.

In this book, Mike and his father-in-law, Charley Stevens, explore the remote regions of northern Maine near the Canadian border. The unique and immersive setting enhances the story's tension and intrigue.
conclusion: This book is a thrilling addition, with its fast-paced plot, immersive setting, and well-developed characters. Fans will appreciate the familiar elements while being captivated by the new dangers and mysteries Mike faces.

review: The story follows Mike Bowditch, a Maine game warden investigator, who becomes intrigued by the disappearance of a man who was asking about a reclusive builder named Redmond and his young daughter, Cady. Teaming up with his father-in-law, Charlie, Mike visits Josie Johnson, a bush pilot and Charlie's friend, who is having a cabin constructed by Redmond. The plot intensifies when events take a dangerous turn, prompting Mike to search for Redmond and Cady, fearing for her safety. The novel is fast-paced and suspenseful, particularly as Mike tracks them toward the Canadian border. A twist adds an unexpected layer of intrigue, keeping readers guessing until the end.

Mike Bowditch is brave and committed, yet his self-assuredness and juvenile attitude make him less likable. However, the dynamics between Mike and Charlie enrich the story, while Josie Johnson’s role as a bush pilot adds an intriguing element.
The north woods of Maine provide a vivid and immersive backdrop that heightens the story's sense of danger and isolation.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a fast-paced and suspenseful mystery that works well as a stand-alone novel, even for readers new to the main character. While the protagonist’s personality may not be entirely likable, the engaging plot, atmospheric setting, and unexpected twists make it an enjoyable read.

review: The book opens with a captivating sense of mystery and intrigue. However, as the story unfolds, it becomes increasingly implausible, especially with the game warden wandering through the wilderness in pursuit of a man he barely knows. The cat-and-mouse chase lacks adequate buildup and would have been more engaging with deeper character development.

I struggled to connect with the protagonist, Mike Bowditch, particularly when he opted for a one-man vendetta instead of calling for backup at the first opportunity. This choice felt unrealistic and undermined his credibility as a character.
The high-intensity moments were expertly crafted, keeping me engaged and eager to finish the book. The author effectively maintained suspense throughout these scenes.
As the story unfolded, its plausibility diminished, particularly regarding the protagonist's actions and decisions. The unrealistic scenarios made it challenging to fully engage with the narrative.
conclusion: While the book had a strong start with its mystery and intrigue, it struggled with maintaining plausibility and character depth as the story unfolded. The high-intensity moments were a highlight, but the overall execution could have been improved with more realistic character decisions and a stronger buildup to the central conflict.
reformatted_ori_review:

- **Plot and Pacing:**  
  The book started off promising with a strong sense of mystery and intrigue. However, the story began to feel implausible as it progressed, particularly with the game warden traipsing across the wilderness in pursuit of a man he knew little about. I felt the cat-and-mouse chase lacked sufficient buildup and could have benefited from more character depth to make the pursuit more compelling.  

- **Character Development:**  
  I found it hard to connect with the protagonist, Mike Bowditch, especially when he chose to go into "action movie vendetta mode" instead of calling for backup at the first opportunity. This decision felt unrealistic and detracted from his credibility as a character.  

- **Writing Style and Intensity:**  
  The high-intensity moments were well-written and kept me engaged, making me want to finish the book. The author did a good job of maintaining suspense during these scenes.  

- **Realism and Plausibility:**  
  The story's plausibility suffered as it progressed, particularly with the protagonist's actions and decisions. The lack of realism in certain scenarios made it harder to fully immerse myself in the narrative.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the book had a strong start with its mystery and intrigue, it struggled with maintaining plausibility and character depth as the story unfolded. The high-intensity moments were a highlight, but the overall execution could have been improved with more realistic character decisions and a stronger buildup to the central conflict.  

**Rating Scores:**  
No specific rating scores were mentioned in the review.

review: In this gripping tale, Mike is sent to a remote area to search for a missing vacationer, highlighting the dangers of neglecting forest safety. The tension escalates when Mike and Charlie encounter a mysterious man, leading to a harrowing turn of events. The trio is drugged and tied to separate trees, plunging them into a dire situation. As Mike follows their trail in a desperate pursuit, the suspense becomes almost unbearable.

In this engaging story, Mike Bowditch, a Maine game warden, has married his best friend, alongside Charlie and Oma. Known for his keen sense of suspicion—an essential trait for his profession—Mike navigates the complexities of his new life with both charm and trepidation.
"Pitch Dark" is the author's best work to date! With each new thriller, his writing continues to improve.
The woods can be unforgiving for those who neglect forest safety. With the weather worsening, are they making their way to the Canadian border?

In this gripping tale, a father and daughter embark on a journey, leaving three others behind, one of whom doesn't make it. As the tension mounts, questions arise: Do they have allies to help them evade the law? Will Mike reach them in time to prevent further tragedy?
conclusion: Pitch Dark by the author is a masterfully crafted thriller that showcases the author's evolving writing prowess. The story, centered around Mike Bowditch's relentless pursuit in the unforgiving Maine wilderness, is packed with tension, suspense, and a palpable sense of danger. The plot is fast-paced, the characters are well-developed, and the atmospheric setting adds depth to the narrative. This is undoubtedly one of the finest works in the genre, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to thriller enthusiasts.

review: The books adhere to a formulaic plot where Mike's curiosity leads him into incidents that stretch the limits of his job description. *Pitch Dark* follows this pattern, providing little innovation or evolution in its storytelling.

Mike Bowditch remains true to his impulsive nature, fierce loyalty, and strong moral compass. However, his lone ranger persona is becoming repetitive and tiresome; I wish the author would evolve his character and reintegrate him into a community. I do appreciate the peripheral characters, as they add depth and variety to the narrative.
The vivid and evocative descriptions of Maine's unspoiled terrain deeply resonated with me, evoking memories of childhood vacations in the region.
conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a continuation that stays true to its formulaic roots but fails to bring significant growth or change to its protagonist. While the setting and supporting characters are highlights, the story itself feels repetitive and lacks the depth needed to stand out.

   - The descriptions of Maine, particularly its unspoiled terrain, are vivid and evocative. They resonated with me personally, as they reminded me of childhood vacations spent in the region.  

- **Overall Enjoyment and Recommendation:**  
   - While I have enjoyed following Mike Bowditch's journey through the Maine landscape, I found *Pitch Dark* to be an average story with little to distinguish it from previous books in the series.  
   - I hesitate to recommend this book to other readers due to its lack of character evolution and narrative innovation.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Pitch Dark* is a continuation of the Mike Bowditch series that stays true to its formulaic roots but fails to bring significant growth or change to its protagonist. While the setting and supporting characters are highlights, the story itself feels repetitive and lacks the depth needed to stand out.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores were mentioned in the review.)  

**Disclaimer:**  
I received an Advanced Reader's Copy of *Pitch Dark* from NetGalley and the publisher. The decision to review this book was entirely my own.

review: This high-octane thriller stars Game Warden Mike Bowditch and is reminiscent of C.J. Box but packs even more action. The clever mystery unfolds with jaw-dropping twists that keep the reader fully engaged. It emphasizes themes of nature, loyalty, and perseverance while steering clear of unrealistic romance and typical mystery clichés.

Mike is unwavering in his pursuit of justice, often at great personal risk. His determination grows stronger when his loved ones are threatened, transforming him into a formidable force. The narrative skillfully weaves in elements of his personal life, including his marriage and impending fatherhood, without overshadowing the main plot. The supporting cast is well-developed, with relatable flaws that make them engaging and endearing. Notable characters like Josie Jonson, the pilot, and Charlie, Mike's father-in-law, enhance the story's depth and richness.

The writing is exceptional, maintaining a strong focus on the main storyline without any distractions. The author expertly balances action, character development, and thematic elements. The tone remains consistent and engaging, steering clear of melodrama and unrealistic aspects.
The novel explores themes of loyalty, justice, and perseverance, all vividly set against a backdrop of nature and action.
conclusion: This is an excellent and engaging novel that delivers a high-octane thriller with a clever mystery, well-developed characters, and top-quality writing. The focus on nature, action, and loyalty, combined with the absence of unrealistic romance or mystery tropes, makes it a standout read.

review: In this gripping tale, Mike Bowditch, a Maine Game Warden, teams up with a rookie warden to investigate a complex missing person case. Their journey leads them deep into the northern woods of Maine, where Mike confronts yet another thrilling and challenging situation alongside his father-in-law, Charley.

Dorian has skillfully developed Mike Bowditch's character. As a warden willing to bend the rules, Mike often finds himself at odds with his superiors. Yet, his unwavering commitment to solving cases makes him a compelling and relatable protagonist.
This story provides a refreshing perspective on police procedurals, making it a must-read for genre enthusiasts. Highly recommended for fans of the genre.

review: The story follows Maine game warden Mike Bowditch as he investigates the disappearance of a man who was inquiring about a reclusive father-daughter duo living off the grid. Mike must then navigate the rugged Maine wilderness to track down their assailant. The narrative is fast-paced and suspenseful, though some action sequences feel a bit far-fetched. The rugged Maine wilderness provides a vivid and immersive backdrop that heightens the story's tension and danger. Its authenticity significantly enhances the plot.

While some elements felt a bit unrealistic, the overall experience was enjoyable, and I look forward to reading more works by this author.

review: This high-octane bush thriller captivated me from start to finish. conclusion: *Pitch Dark* is a thrilling and well-crafted novel that works brilliantly as a standalone. With its engaging plot, likable protagonist, and excellent narration, it kept me hooked until the very end. The clever twist and moral dilemma added depth, making it a memorable read.
